fields.headline: Misery lines
fields.bodyText: The GNER spokesman's claim that high walk-on fares are "aimed at the business market" (RMT rails against high fares, April 22) ignores people visiting relatives taken ill or travelling to funerals. Operators' willingness to profit from passengers' misery is matched only by the government's tolerance of this piracy. Michael Sargent Aylesbury, Bucks Happily any limits on immigration set by either Howard or Blair will not apply to the 380 million citizens of the EU, free to come and live and work in the UK at any time. Makes limiting immigration a bit of a nonsense doesn't it? Stephen Walkley Lutterworth, Leics Those suspicious of the recent outbreak of love between Blair and Brown may enjoy noting that Granita, the trendy, minimalist restaurant where their original, untrustworthy deal was hatched, is now a Tex-Mex establishment called Desperados. Jack Winkler London Greatest Pole in history - has everyone forgotten Chopin (Letters, April 23)? Paul Tinnion Newcastle upon Tyne The Co-op is under siege from Tesco (Co-op's profits halved, April 21). More of us must try to shop at our local Co-ops before we lose the chain that sells lots of fair-trade food and biodegradable bags. Janet Hackney Hyde, Cheshire All of you who use 35mm canisters for toothpaste, suncream, salt and pepper or other food items might like to know that chemicals from the film can be cleansed by a common salt solution left in the canister for a week. Stuart Dodson Kirmington, Lincs
